claim: Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was a founding participant of the UN.

supporting.text: The Ukrainian SSR was one of the original signatories of the United Nations Charter in 1945, which confirms its founding participation.

attacks.text: The Ukrainian SSR was one of the original signatories of the United Nations Charter in 1945, which confirms its founding participation.
The Ukrainian SSR was not an independent state but a constituent republic of the USSR, which undermines its claim as a founding participant.
Signing the UN Charter does not equate to full founding participation, as the Ukrainian SSR had limited autonomy in international affairs.
Despite being part of the USSR, the Ukrainian SSR had its own seat and vote in the UN General Assembly, indicating a level of recognition.
The UN Charter explicitly lists the Ukrainian SSR as an original member, which legally affirms its founding status.
The Ukrainian SSR's UN seat was largely symbolic, as foreign policy was controlled by Moscow, limiting its actual participation.
Legal recognition does not negate the fact that the Ukrainian SSR lacked sovereignty, which is central to being a founding participant.

supporting.text: The Ukrainian SSR had a separate seat in the UN General Assembly despite being part of the USSR, demonstrating its distinct founding role.

attacks.text: The Ukrainian SSR had a separate seat in the UN General Assembly despite being part of the USSR, demonstrating its distinct founding role.
The separate seat was a symbolic gesture by the USSR to increase its voting power, not a recognition of Ukraine's sovereignty.
The Ukrainian SSR lacked true independent decision-making in the UN, as it followed USSR directives.
Symbolic or not, the separate seat legally established Ukraine's participation in the UN's founding framework.
Many UN members at the time also lacked full sovereignty but were still recognized as distinct participants.
Legal participation does not equate to meaningful agency, which is required for true founding status.
Comparisons to other non-sovereign members ignore Ukraine's unique subordination to USSR foreign policy.

supporting.text: Historical records from the UN's founding conference in San Francisco list the Ukrainian SSR as an attending delegation, supporting its founding status.

attacks.text: Historical records from the UN's founding conference in San Francisco list the Ukrainian SSR as an attending delegation, supporting its founding status.
Attendance does not necessarily equate to founding participation, as the Ukrainian SSR was not an independent state but a constituent republic of the USSR.
The Ukrainian SSR's role was largely symbolic, as real decision-making power at the UN resided with the Soviet Union.
The UN Charter explicitly lists the Ukrainian SSR as a founding member, which legally confirms its status regardless of its relationship with the USSR.
Symbolic participation is still a form of participation, and the Ukrainian SSR had its own seat and vote in the General Assembly.
The legal status of the Ukrainian SSR as a founding member was a political concession to the USSR and does not reflect genuine statehood or independence.
Having a seat and vote does not imply meaningful autonomy, as the Ukrainian SSR's foreign policy was controlled by Moscow.

supporting.text: The Ukrainian SSR's participation was largely symbolic, as it was under full political control of the USSR and did not act independently in UN matters.

attacks.text: The Ukrainian SSR's participation was largely symbolic, as it was under full political control of the USSR and did not act independently in UN matters.
The Ukrainian SSR had its own seat, flag, and voting rights in the UN General Assembly, demonstrating formal independence in UN proceedings.
Historical records show Ukrainian SSR representatives occasionally took stances differing from the USSR on certain UN matters, indicating some autonomy.
While the Ukrainian SSR had formal UN trappings, all major decisions were cleared with Moscow first, making its independence superficial.
The few instances of divergent positions were on minor issues and didn't affect Soviet bloc unity on key votes.
Even symbolic participation required some operational autonomy in UN procedures, which contradicts claims of total subordination.
Minor divergences created important precedents that later facilitated Ukraine's full independence in international affairs.

supporting.text: The term 'founding participant' is misleading because the Ukrainian SSR was not a sovereign state but a constituent republic of the USSR, which was the true founding member.

attacks.text: The term 'founding participant' is misleading because the Ukrainian SSR was not a sovereign state but a constituent republic of the USSR, which was the true founding member.
The Ukrainian SSR had its own seat and voting rights in the UN General Assembly, which indicates a level of international recognition beyond a typical constituent republic.
Historical documents show that the Ukrainian SSR actively participated in UN proceedings and signed the UN Charter, fulfilling criteria of a founding participant.
The Ukrainian SSR's UN membership was largely symbolic, as it followed USSR foreign policy and lacked independent decision-making power.
Signing the UN Charter does not equate to sovereign statehood, as other non-sovereign entities have also signed international treaties under sponsorship.
Symbolic recognition can still carry legal weight in international law, as seen in other cases of non-sovereign entities with UN participation rights.
The Ukrainian SSR's ability to independently advocate for its interests in UN committees contradicts the claim of pure subordination to USSR policy.

supporting.text: International law at the time recognized the USSR as the sole legal entity, undermining claims of the Ukrainian SSR's independent participation in the UN's founding.

attacks.text: International law at the time recognized the USSR as the sole legal entity, undermining claims of the Ukrainian SSR's independent participation in the UN's founding.
The Ukrainian SSR had its own seat and vote in the UN General Assembly, which indicates a level of independent participation despite being part of the USSR.
Historical documents show that the Ukrainian SSR signed the UN Charter as a separate entity, which contradicts the claim that it was not independently recognized.

The USSR's constitution allowed republics limited international engagement, but ultimate authority rested with Moscow, meaning the Ukrainian SSR's UN participation was symbolic rather than independent.
Signing the UN Charter does not necessarily imply full sovereignty, as other non-sovereign entities have also signed international treaties under their parent state's authority.
Symbolic participation still constitutes participation, and the Ukrainian SSR's UN seat allowed it to voice its interests separately from the USSR on certain occasions.
The act of signing as a separate entity, regardless of sovereignty, demonstrates that the international community acknowledged the Ukrainian SSR's distinct role in the UN's founding.
